    df_apply

    df_apply.Rmd
    library(newprojdata303)

    Description

    This function takes in a data frame, a function, and a filter. The function can be applied to a column of a data frame and return the column of the dataframe. The filter will return either a true or false.

    Use

    df_apply(.data, .fun, .filter, …)

    Our team used df_apply to round the lengths and widths of iris petals using the R preset iris data frame. (This would be useful when precision isn’t needed and the user wants to round to integers before analysis.) To use df_apply() to round numbers, simply use the premade function round() in the place of .fun, with is.numeric() as .filter and the data frame of your choice:

    iris_function <- df_apply(iris, round, is.numeric)

    The function can be used with any data set, mutate function, and filter function. The filter function will be applied to all columns, one by one, checking whether a condition is true. For instance, to change all text in a data frame to upper case, we can use the is.character() function as a filter, than apply the toupper() function to change columns of characters to upper case.

    The df_apply() function returns an updated data frame.

    General requirements

    Pass the df_apply function:

    1. a data frame
    2. a function which can be applied to a vector and change it
    3. a function which can take a vector and check whether a condition is true for that vector (for instance, whether it contains a certain data type)

    On this page
